predictions.reasoning: First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) adding new AI provider integration without tests or maintainer engagement. Pattern P-1-6 applies: new provider addition PRs from first-time contributors lack tests, have no human reviewer approval, and no maintainer label/comment. Automated reviews (greptile-apps) identify technical issues but author is only engaging with bot ('review again?' x3). Member comment from sebslight appears to be a closing statement ('If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen'). No human reviewer approval or maintainer label present.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with XS-sized extension PR. Only automated reviews present (greptile-apps identifies critical security issue: 'Removed webhook security config' but downstream Twilio/Plivo still reference it). Zero human reviewer comments, zero approvals. Pattern P-1-9 applies: first-time contributors with zero reviews and zero comments have low merge probability. The identified security regression (webhook config removal) makes this a blocking issue without maintainer intervention.

Author w0s1nsk1 has 0% merge rate (1 prior PR, 0 merged). Despite 12 comments showing active engagement and iterative fixes responding to automated review feedback, all reviews are from bots (greptile-apps, chatgpt-codex-connector). Zero human reviewer comments, zero approvals. Pattern P-4-1 applies: authors with 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs are unlikely to merge new PRs even with approval signals from non-maintainer reviewers. Engagement alone without human reviewer approval does not overcome 0% author history. The PR touches extensions and shows multiple rounds of iteration, but lack of human reviewer validation is terminal.

Reopened PR from w0s1nsk1 (now 2 prior PRs, 0 merged, 0% merge rate). Author states 'Closing and reopening as a fresh PR (per request) to reset review state.' However, this is still the same author with persistent 0% merge rate, and the reopening itself signals that the previous iteration (#10488) was not merged. Zero human reviewer comments on this instance, only automated reviews (greptile-apps, chatgpt-codex-connector). Pattern P-4-1 and P-4-3 apply: 0% merge rate across 2+ prior PRs without human reviewer engagement remains a non-merge signal. Strategic reopening does not overcome author history without new human reviewer intervention.

Author coygeek (14 prior PRs, 2 merged, 14.3% merge rate) has explicitly closed this PR themselves. The author's final comment states: 'Cleanup note for traceability: - Linked issue #11024 was closed by maintainer as duplicate of #5120. - Keeping discussion/work tracking under canonical issue #5120 (linked issue closed as duplicate; canonical issue remains open). Closing this PR to align with duplicate routing.' This is an explicit self-closure based on canonical issue deduplication, not a maintainer rejection. Pattern P-3-1 applies: author comment stating PR is superseded/related to duplicate issue = terminal non-merge signal. PR is already closed by author.

Author alfadb (12 prior PRs, 0 merged, 0% merge rate) — persistent non-merger despite multiple submissions. PR has one author comment showing engagement (follow-up commit with type alignment), but all 3 reviews are automated (greptile-apps, chatgpt-codex-connector, copilot-pull-request-reviewer). Zero human reviewer comments, zero approvals. Pattern P-4-1 applies: authors with 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs (12 in this case) are unlikely to merge new PRs even with iterative improvements. Focused scope (2 files, agents category) and tests present do not overcome entrenched non-merge history without human reviewer approval.

Author 0xRaini (86 prior PRs, 15 merged, 17.4% merge rate, top contributor) closed this PR themselves with explicit statement: 'Closing this — AbortSignal.timeout() is the correct modern API here, the manual controller approach is a step backwards. My mistake.' This is a self-directed closure by the author recognizing the approach was incorrect. Despite the author's strong history (ranked top contributor), the explicit technical rejection of their own approach makes merge impossible. No human reviewer approval present (only codex usage limit message). Pattern: terminal self-closure by author overrides positive author history.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with XL-sized PR (63 files) containing personal agent memory/setup files ('Faheem/' directory with business/learning/personal/health subdirectories). This appears to be accidental repository pollution or personal fork content. Pattern P-2-4 applies: XL-sized PRs from first-time contributors without maintainer labels are unlikely to merge regardless of author engagement. Additional signal: the PR content (personal business plans, health habits, meal plans) is clearly not intended for the main repository. Only one automated review present (greptile-apps with minimal comment). This is not a legitimate contribution to the project.

PR explicitly labeled 'close:superseded' and contributor Takhoffman (CONTRIBUTOR role) has commented: 'Closing as superseded. This appears superseded because the same fix is already in main, including the behavior change, test coverage, and changelog entry' with commit hash reference. Pattern P-3-1 applies: explicit supersession comment from contributor constitutes terminal non-merge signal. Additionally, there is a CI failure (expected 408 got 400) that the author did not address. The supersession statement is definitive regardless of author's 57.1% merge rate on prior PRs.

Author jleechan2015 (1 prior PR, 0 merged, 0% merge rate) has explicitly self-closed this PR with comment: 'Closing - pushing to jleechanorg/openclaw instead'. This is author-initiated closure indicating they are moving the work to a fork/alternative location. Pattern: explicit author closure statement = terminal non-merge signal, regardless of other factors. Additionally, this is an L-sized PR (8 files) from a first-time contributor without maintainer engagement, fitting P-2-4 pattern anyway. The self-closure is definitive.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with security fix. While the PR has an approval from orzelig and passing CI (per author's final status update), the critical pattern is P-1-9: 'First-time contributors with a maintainer label but zero human reviewer comments or approvals do not reliably merge, even with focused scope and tests.' This PR lacks a maintainer label entirely. Additionally, sebslight's MEMBER comment ('If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen') appears to be a closure notice without explicit merge approval language. The absence of maintainer engagement combined with first-time contributor status and lack of maintainer label signals non-merge despite technical quality.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with a simple 2-file fix. sebslight's MEMBER comment ('If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen') is a closure notice. Terminal non-merge signal: Pattern P-3-3 explicitly states 'PRs with 270+ files and 20+ labels are closed by automated triage as 'too noisy' regardless of content quality or author association.' This PR has 628 files changed and 16 labels (exceeds 20-label threshold). The openclaw-barnacle bot closure comment confirms: 'Closing this PR because it has more than 20 labels, which usually means the branch is too noisy.' This is an automated triage closure, terminal signal overriding all other factors. First-time contributor with 0.0% merge rate compounds the signal.

Author has 6 prior PRs with 0% merge rate (0 merged). Author's follow-up comment acknowledges the closure and requests reopening, comparing this PR to #8402 (suggesting possible supersession). While the PR has experienced-contributor label and 'size: S', the combination of persistent 0% merge rate across 6+ PRs, closure by maintainer, and comparison to another PR (#8402) indicates this PR was closed in favor of the alternative. No explicit merge receipt or maintainer approval present.

This language indicates the PR was superseded by another PR that already merged with equivalent or superior functionality. Terminal positive merge signal: Pattern P-2-2 applies. steipete CONTRIBUTOR comment includes explicit merge language ('Landed via temp rebase onto main') with commit reference ('Land commit:', 'Merge commit:'). Greptile flags 3 distinct architectural bugs: (1) stopSharedClient() with no key stops ALL shared clients, (2) wrong account client selection in resolveMatrixClient, (3) accountId ignored for shared auth. Author responds to comments but greptile keeps flagging issues across multiple rounds, suggesting the implementation has structural problems. Zero human reviewer approvals, no maintainer label, community comment notes original issue (#5292) not fixed. Pattern P-4-1 applies: XL-sized PR from first-time contributor without human reviewer approval/maintainer label = unlikely merge. Multiple architectural issues flagged by AI reviewer compound the non-merge signal. The iterative cycle without resolution suggests the PR is problematic.

Author (hclsys) explicitly closes the PR with statement: 'Closing — this was superseded by upstream changes.' This is a direct supersession closure statement from the author (CONTRIBUTOR). Pattern P-3-1 applies: 'PRs where a contributor comment stating another PR supersedes the original are not merged.' Even though the author has 14 prior PRs with 7.1% merge rate (not extreme), the explicit closure comment is a terminal non-merge signal. The author states the issue was resolved elsewhere ('upstream changes').

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with minimal change (1 file: docker-compose.yml). Only greptile automated review present, zero human comments/approvals, no maintainer label. Title 'sync openclaw main' suggests a sync/merge operation rather than a focused feature fix, which is a red flag. Greptile review present (4 comments) suggests identified issues. Pattern P-11-1 applies: zero human engagement + zero approval from first-time contributor = low merge. The vague title and lack of clarity on what is being synced amplifies non-merge signal.

Only greptile automated review present (1 comment flagging concerns), zero human reviewer comments or approvals, no maintainer label, no comments. Focused scope and clear intent, but zero human engagement. Pattern P-11-1 applies: first-time contributor + zero human reviews/comments + zero approval = low merge. However, this PR appears to be superseded by PR #10905 from Zazarothh which addresses the same issue with broader scope. See duplicates section.

Author Zazarothh has 3 prior PRs with 0% merge rate (0/3 merged). New PR fixing Windows null device redirection in PowerShell (3 files, XS scope). Only greptile automated review present (1 comment), zero human reviewer engagement, no maintainer label. The author's consistent non-merge history combined with continued zero human engagement predicts closure.

Author Zazarothh has 5 prior PRs with 0% merge rate (0/5 merged). PR fixes WhatsApp filename preservation (6 files, M scope), touching both agents and whatsapp-web. Critically, community comment from DeveshParagiri explicitly marks as 'Duplicate #10889' (likely should be #10866). Zazarothh's author comment/history indicates low merge probability. Combined with author's 0% merge rate across 5 prior PRs and no human reviewer engagement, this PR will not merge.

Author 0xRaini is an experienced contributor (81 prior PRs, 17.3% merge rate, MEMBER association). However, author explicitly closes the PR with comment: 'Closing duplicate — same issue'. This is a direct duplicate closure statement from the author. Pattern P-3-1 applies: explicit duplicate/supersession comment is a terminal non-merge signal, regardless of author history or prior merge rate. The author is closing their own PR as a duplicate, indicating the issue is being addressed elsewhere. The fact that this comes from a high-engagement contributor reinforces the closure decision.

Terminal positive merge signal: Contributor mbelinky (CONTRIBUTOR role) explicitly states 'Merging into new alpha code path' with cherry-pick attribution preserved. This is a commit-hash-backed merge receipt equivalent (P-2-2: explicit merge language from a contributor). Despite first-time contributor status (0 prior PRs) and XS size, the merge receipt comment overrides all negative signals. Category: app-level security hardening (ATS). Small scope (2 files, focused).

XL-sized PR (9 files, labeled size:XL) from first-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate). PR with 1068 files changed — far exceeds reasonable scope. Greptile automated review explicitly flags: 'Too many files changed for review. (1068 files found, 100 file limit)'. Author vignesh07 has strong prior history (4 prior PRs, 4 merged, 100% merge rate). PR has maintainer label and docs + discord channel labels (size: 5 files = M). Author coygeek has low merge rate (21 prior PRs, 3 merged, 14.3% merge rate = low-merge author). duplicates.evidence: PRs #10481, #10488, and #10520 are sequential iterations from the same author (w0s1nsk1) on the identical voice-call/asterisk-ari provider feature. Same 9 files changed across all three PRs. #10488 incorporates feedback from #10481. #10520 explicitly states 'Closing and reopening as a fresh PR (per request) to reset review state', indicating #10488 was superseded by this reopening. These are iteration cycles on a single feature, not independent contributions. Only the latest (#10520) should be evaluated as the active PR; earlier two are development iterations.

Both PRs address zip path traversal / zip slip attack prevention in archive extraction. PR #3687 (MaxMiksa) and PR #5322 (afurm) both modify src/infra/archive.ts and src/infra/archive.test.ts with the same security fix. Both are 3-file changes with identical scope. PR #3687 created 2026-01-29, PR #5322 created 2026-01-31 (2 days later), suggesting #5322 may be a duplicate submission or independent discovery of the same issue. Both are from first-time contributors with 0% prior merge rates. Both received closure-style maintainer comments from sebslight without explicit merge approval.

Both are first-time contributor fixes (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with 2-file changes that address config/integration issues. Both received closure-style maintainer comments from sebslight ('If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen'). However, PR #4196 addresses firecrawl schema config while #9833 addresses cron timer logic, so they are distinct features. The overlap is pattern-level (closure signal, first-time contributor) rather than semantic duplication. Low confidence in true duplicate.

Both are first-time contributor PRs with XS/S scope closed by similar maintainer comments. However, #3687 is a security fix (zip extraction) while #9833 is a cron timing fix. No semantic overlap. Confidence reflects only the similar closure pattern and author profile, not true duplication.

Identical PR titles ('perf(gateway): reduce idle CPU by increasing config/manifest cache TTL to 5s'), same author (VintLin), created 8 minutes apart (2026-02-08T02:52:10Z vs 02:58:35Z), identical files changed (src/config/io.ts + src/plugins/manifest-registry.ts). PR #11627 has critical automated review comment identifying determinism bug; #11628 has zero engagement. High confidence #11628 is a resubmission after #11627 received negative review feedback.

PR #7907 (Ahmed14z) explicitly closes in favor of #7849 stating 'covers all channels...at the resolveAttachmentMaxBytes level.' Both are mediaMaxMb config fixes from Feb 3–4. #7849 is then superseded by #11093 (per member comment). Clear supersession chain: #7907 → #7849 → #11093. Both will close without independent merge.

Both are new provider addition PRs (nano-gpt.com and Maple AI) from first-time contributors created within 1 day of each other. Both touch docs, commands, agents categories and follow similar implementation patterns. However, they are distinct providers with different implementations and integration points, so not true duplicates. Low confidence as these appear to be independent parallel work rather than supersessions.

Both PRs explicitly closed by first-time authors with comments stating 'Closing in favor of a [rebased/squashed] PR'. Both feature responsive author engagement with review feedback before closure. Both are resubmit patterns rather than true duplicates of each other. No direct PR cross-reference indicates these are separate resubmissions, not duplicates of one another.

All three PRs report 0 files changed despite listing files in the diff. This is a consistent data anomaly across the batch, suggesting either a metadata parsing error, a batch processing issue, or corrupted PR metadata. These may represent a class of malformed/empty PRs rather than duplicates of each other, but the shared 0-file anomaly warrants investigation.

PR #10905 from Zazarothh includes explicit comment from DeveshParagiri (author of #10866) stating 'Duplicate #10889' (likely referencing #10866). Both PRs address the same issue: preserving WhatsApp document filename during send operations. PR #10905 spans 6 files (includes agents + whatsapp-web) while #10866 spans 3 files (whatsapp-web only). PR #10905 appears to be the broader/newer iteration that supersedes #10866. Files overlap significantly: src/web/active-listener.ts, src/web/inbound/send-api.ts, src/web/outbound.ts appear in both.

Both PRs involve feature additions to core platform (gateway/UI and skills respectively), but thematic overlap is minimal. PR #8462 is a dashboard feature for token/session analytics; PR #9186 is a skill marketplace addition. No explicit supersession or duplicate language in comments. Low confidence - likely distinct features.

PR #14350 comment from steipete (MEMBER): 'We decided not to take this PR path and instead hardened the project directly in main via security audit coverage and defaults guidance' with explicit reference to audit checks. Author saurabhsh5 then states in subsequent comment: 'I have added the missing audit checks in this PR' (referencing PR #15757). Not a traditional duplicate, but #14350 is superseded by the combined approach of main hardening + #15757.
No duplicate detected for PR #10843. This is a scope-out-of-bounds PR (moltbook skills should go to clawhub, not this repo). Not a duplicate of another PR in the batch.

No duplicate/superseded groups detected among the PRs in this batch. PR #18010 was reverted per maintainer comment, but there is no indication it was superseded by a different PR number in this batch. Other PRs address distinct features/fixes (shell-audit, discord fix, QMD memory scoping, BlueBubbles auth, Slack docs, config option, Docker deploy, i18n localization) with no obvious duplicate targets.
